name: Google I/O 2016 Extended / Kickoff

group.name: Google Developer Group of the Capital Region

description:
This is a kickoff of a brand new chapter of Google Developer Groups in the Capital Region. This I/O Extended event gets us together to discuss technology interests, and recent announcements from Google:

Be sure to check out theÂ Google I/O scheduleÂ andÂ videos before the meetup.

Working Agenda:

Introduction and overview of Google Developer Groups and the GDG Capital Region chapter in particular. We will be looking for input from you on topics and whether you'd like talks, demos, codelabs, etc.

Lightning overview of Google I/O announcements and technologies featured during I/O 2016.

Talk by Apprenda engineering (topic to be announced)

Pick a Google I/O session to stream while networking and discussing how GDG Capital Region can best serve the local developer community.

Wrapup

name: Using Go Lang at MadGlory and Progressive Web App Code Lab

group.name: Google Developer Group of the Capital Region

description:
Our meeting in June will feature a talk in the first 3rd of the evening about the Go Programming Language. We'll follow that up with a quick intro level code lab on building progressive web apps. Lastly, as always, there will be plenty of time for open conversation and networking at the end of the evening.

This will be our last meeting before a short Summer break, so make sure to make it out to the amazing Apprenda space again for this one.

Agenda:

Brian Corrigan and the crew from MadGlory will talk about a new video gaming platform they're building with Go called Jigsaw.

The MadGlory team has a reputation in the Capital Region as one of the coolest dev shops around. It will be awesome to see what they're working on next. Check them out at www.madglory.com

Progressive Web App Code Lab: We'll watch the keynote from the Google Progressive Web App summit happening in Amsterdam. Following the keynote we'll dive into the code lab.

The Progressive Web App Code LabÂ is designed to introduce us to the design considerations and best practices for designing mobile web apps. We'll be building an entry level weather web app using Progressive Web App techniques.

You'll only need your laptop with Google Chrome and your favorite text editor installed to participate.

Conversation: This will be the last meeting before the Summer break, so make sure you're here to participate in the conversations that will follow. Take the time to chat with friends and make some new ones :)
how_to_find_us: Check in with security at the ground level and come on up to the 4th floor. The Apprenda cafeteria is opposite from the doors to the front desk.

name: September meetup: Golang and IoT; and Polymer hands-on and demo

group.name: Google Developer Group of the Capital Region

description:
Welcome back! We have some great tech content and announcements!

Format will be similar to past events with networking on both ends of the event and two technical presentations/demos/Q&A sessions.

This meetup features Golang meets IoT, with a custom Golang server running on an embedded Samsung ARTIK-10 ARM IoT development board and 2 of three instances of RethinkDB running on on a second ARTIK-10, along with NATS messaging for water flow readings. The configuration and operation of the overall is facilitated by an Ionic hybrid mobile application. Demo video and code walkthrough will be provided.

We'll also present on Polymer. You'll need to show up to see what that's all about!

See you all there. Bring your friends and colleagues!

GDG organizers (Jason and Kris)

name: RxJS and Kubernetes

group.name: Google Developer Group of the Capital Region

description:
Reminder: Sign up for DevFest at:

https://www.eventbrite.com/e/capital-region-devfest-2016-tickets-27789179183

Capital Region DevFest 2016 website:

http://gdgcapitalregion.bitbucket.io

=======================

10/18 meetup information

=======================

Hello GDGCR members. Please join us for a Northern venue meetup. Informz has a great space and we look forward to seeing our normal Troy attendees in Saratoga Springs, as well as those from the Northern part of the Capital Region!

=======================================================

Agenda:

1. Networking portion

=======================

2. Opening remarks from Informz

=======================

3.Â Getting Started with Reactive Programming and RxJS -Â Zack Fantauzzi, Railroad19

Reactive programming isn’t new, but it is getting a lot of attention due to its heavy use by Netflix and its inclusion in Angular 2.0.Â 

We’ll start the discussion by understanding what kind of problems the reactive programming paradigm solves. By understanding the ‘why’ and ‘where’ we’ll be able to understand the ‘when’ of using a reactive style of programming.

After understanding the reasons for using a reactive pattern we’ll discuss what kind of tools/frameworks are available and then settle on RxJS. RxJS isn’t the only option, but it is the framework of choice for both Netflix and the Angular team. We’ll look at some examples and basic usages to illustrate getting started with RxJS and talk about some resources available for learning more.Â 

=======================

4. Building a Microservices Platform with Kubernetes - Matthew Mark Miller, Apprenda Architect

This is a preview of a talk Matthew will deliver in SF at QCon in November.

See:

https://qconsf.com/sf2016/users/mark-matthew-miller

We have the distinct pleasure of providing feedback to and interacting with to Matthew, as he represents Apprenda at some of the highest levels in the Open Source, Cloud-Native Computing space.

Abstract:

A microservices architecture makes software easier to build and deploy with high availability using decoupled teams. The trade-off for this is increased complexity for deployment, operations and a high potential for duplication of labor.
One way to control these trade-offs is to build domain specific services on top of a common platform.

Kubernetes is a container orchestration system open sourced by Google and incubated by the Cloud Native Computing Foundation (CNCF). Far from simply moving and monitoring jailed processes, Kubernetes adds higher level abstractions that make the introduction of platform type behaviors easier while maintaining the microservices goals of high availability and team independence.

We will review Kubernetes’ primitives and walk through the implementation of some common microservices patterns on top of them, including rolling deployments, stateful services and adding behaviors via sidecars.

=======================================================

See you on 10/18 folks.

Jason and Kris

name: 2017 Kickoff Meetup

group.name: Google Developer Group of the Capital Region

description:
Thanks to our great community, we had a great 2016. What a ride, right up to DevFestCR2016 (see the recap video at:

https://www.youtube.com/embed/_5baoZnZJOA

). 2017 is shaping up to be a great year for the Capital Region Google Developer Group also! Be sure not to miss DevFestCR2017 later in the year and signature events through the year!

Join us at Apprenda HQ for food, drink, networking and great technical content.

Here is the agenda:

More details:

Nitya Narasimhan will join usnd get us up to speed using React and Firebase together. Thanks Nitya!

After this, Adam Fish fromÂ Realm.ioÂ will be joining via WebEx to present their their embedded database technology, also called Realm, which can be used with Android, as well as other mobile platforms, including iOS and React Native. Thanks Adam!

Closing announcements:

For fans of the backend, we also have early information about Google Cloud Next 2017: https://cloudnext.withgoogle.com

In addition, for those interested in Golang, we have a special offer to extend for those that attend. It will be well worth the free food and great company ðŸ˜€

name: Cloud Next Extended (bring your laptops and check out the codelabs)

group.name: Google Developer Group of the Capital Region

description:
If you want to learn about or get your hands on some of the latest Google Cloud Platform (GCP) services discussed at Cloud Next, such as BigQuery, Container Engine, Cloud Functions, Cloud Dataflow, or Cloud Machine Learning, this is an event that you simply cannot afford to miss. We are bringing a sampling of GoogleÂ Cloud Next directly to you.

Google Cloud Next was held in San Francisco from 3/8 - 3/10, and the content was extremely interesting on all fronts. Consider previewing the videos of the event at:Â 

https://goo.gl/59bGVE

These videosÂ are a wealth of information. Be sure to let us know your favorite session!

==========

We will kick off the event by seeing all of the amazing services announced at Cloud Next.

Next, we will hear from RPI Professor, Jason Kuruzovich about how to leverage kubernetes for data analytics in his talk, entitledÂ Kubernetes and Jupyter as a Platform for Analytics.

Abstract:Â The Jupyter notebook and server-based Jupyterhub help to solve the division between concepts and computation, providing a single platform in which information and the associated computational examples can be demonstrated. Jupyter supports multiple different languages (R, Python, Spark, Scala, Haskell, Ruby, etc.), integrates presentations, written content including sophisticated encodings such as LaTeX, supports a cloud deployment, and can be paired with an autograder. Â Externally, Jupyter notebooks are being used in Google's DataLab Project, IBM's Data Science Experience, and Microsoft's Azure ML Studio.Â 

I’ll demonstrate a few examples of using Google API’s (Translate, Vision) from Jupyter notebooks.

Jason Kuruzovich is Director of the Severino Center for Technological Entrepreneurship and Associate Professor of Business Analytics at RPI

Jason is an academic entrepreneur who works on problems in which analytics can have a meaningful impact. Through his role as Director of the Severino Center for Technological Entrepreneurship, Jason manages a wide variety of programs to encourage entrepreneurship through contexts, communities, and mentorship opportunities. Jason has been directly involved in the launch of numerous entrepreneurship programs including Foundry-RPI, Startup Tech Valley meetup, NSF Funded NYS Capital Region I-Corp Site Program (PI for grant). He has been recognized as one of the Albany Business Review’s 40 under 40 in the Capital Region and received the Center for Economic Growth (CEG) Technology Innovation Award. He also received the 2016 Upstate Venture Connect Campus Connector Award. Jason also teaches the Technology Foundations and the Capstone course for the RPI MS Business Analytics program, which was ranked 3rd in the world by TFE Times.Â  His latest project the AnalyticsDojo.com is aimed at providing high quality analytics Education to students and enterprises.

We are pleased and honored to have Jason Kuruzovich share his experiences to kick off this event.

==========

Make sure to bring your laptops to this event, as we will have a generous supply of free tokens to allow us to get hands-on with the GCP codelabs (check them out here). In addition to the credits we will have for the event, we will also be giving away codelab credits during the event, so you can do even more with GCP after you leave. Don't miss out! We will be focusing on Node.js during this event, due to its popularity, and since many accessible codelabs coverign Node.js are available to explore.

==========

We will be covering some of the most intriguing technical and partnership announcements from Cloud Next '17 ... and this is going to be a MAJOR CHALLENGE, since there are so many announcements to point to, from Cloud Spanner GA to Cloud Function Beta to partnerships with Improbable (SpatialIO) to ... (well, you get the idea)

At this Cloud Next Extended event, you will, in particular:

• get an overview of the most exciting developments taking place on GCP

•Â get hands-on with CodeLabs featuring Node.js, including:

• web apps powered by Node.js

• Slack bot integration with Node.js

• a GRPC codelab

• Learn about leveraging data analytics and using the Google Brain APIs

... and much more.

We are looking forward to bringing you an engaging and valuable event.

See you there! Oh yeah, this is all FREE of charge!

Jason, Kris and Tanya

name: CLOUD NATIVE: kubernetes: Apprenda talk/demo and kubernetes @ GitHub

group.name: Google Developer Group of the Capital Region

description:
Update: Google provided kubernetes swag for the event! Thanks Google!

7/21/2017 marks the 2nd Birthday of Kubernetes! To commemorate, we are holding an event at the headquarters of a very strong Kubernetes community contributor, Apprenda!Â Â SeeÂ CNCF.ioÂ andÂ kubernetes.ioÂ for more information about the Kubernetes project and complimentary projects.

We have two great talks/demos lined up:

First up is Apprenda's own Steve Wade. Steve is a Principal Kubernetes Consultant from London. Steve will talk about some monitoring and alerting best practices learned from working with Kubernetes customers and demo how Prometheus, Grafana and Slack can be used to monitor, visualize and alert on both the Kubernetes platform as well as application workloads.

After Steve, the Capital Region's own Aaron Brown, a Site Reliability Engineer at Github,Â will dive into why GitHub started using Kubernetes, how they approached migrating their most visible services without downtime, and the challenges they encountered along the way.

These are two high quality presentations that we want to make sure you do not miss, so make sure to sign up and we will see you there.

Format:

6:00pm - 6:30pm: networking, food and drinks (thanks Apprenda! for sponsoring)

6:30pm - 7:15pm: Steve Wade's talk/demo including Q&A

7:15pm - 7:30pm: Intermission and networking

7:30pm - 8:15pm: Aaron Brown's talkÂ including Q&A

8:15pm - 8:30: wrapup and final networking, more food and drink for the road

See you there!

name: Building a New Horizon

group.name: Google Developer Group of the Capital Region

description:
Please join the Capital Region GDG community for this inclusive event (every member of the community is invited). The event theme is: "Building a New Horizon".

The goal of the event is to inspire you to envision how your involvement in the tech industry does, or could, impact the world, or even a small corner of it.

We'll bring you two inspirational and motivating keynotes from Pamela Pavliscak and Janet Carmosky, as well as networking periods and lightning talks.

Pamela is an author, founder and speaker who focuses on human / technology interaction.

Janet is the Executive Director of Albany Can Code, where she is focused on equipping aspiring software developers with the tools to enter this field and excel.

Both Pamela and Janet are engaging speakers and each have a wealth of experience in and around the tech industry.

In addition to Pamela and Janet, we will have networking and lightning talks as well! Our venue host, CommerceHub will be providing the space and food/drink. Great thanks to CommerceHub!

So, if you would like to gather to share experiences and build each other's confidence in how the technology industry can be impacted with our collective skills, please do join us!

Agenda:

10:00am - 10:30am: networking and refreshments
10:30am - 11:15am: Keynote #1
11:15am - 11:45am: Lightning talks
11:45am - 12:30pm: Networking and group interaction
12:30pm - 1:15pm: Keynote #2
1:15pm - end: Networking

Pamela's Keynote:

Title:
How to Create a Human Future with Machines

Summary:
Depending on how you look, you can see two futures for our lives with technology. Put on your rose-colored VR headset and you’ll see the promise of unparalleled ease. Scroll, bleary-eyed through your social media feed and you’ll spot all manner of dystopian futures. Yet, the goal of designers, developers, and anyone creating tech futures is to make the world tangibly better. How do we design a human future with machines? In this session, we'll try out 3 ways to shift our perspective and move beyond boom and doom.

Janet's Keynote:

Software Across our Society and Culture

We're all aware of how many aspects of our functioning in the economy and society are intermediated - in fact shaped - by software. We're also aware that our dependence on apps and devices is increasing, and the aspects of our lives that do not yet involve software are vanishing rapidly. These facts should call into question what role technology companies and software developers play in our culture as a whole. For those of us who are economically secure, stable, and well educated, technology presents opportunities for greater productivity. What does the seemingly irreversible ascendancy of software mean for those of us who are not economically secure, stable, and well educated? Who is being left out, and what do all of us lose when the makers of technology do not represent the full diversity of our society? How can we view a drive to increase diversity in the developer community, and code literacy across the board, as an imperative rather than an option?

Come for these great talks and our lightning talk session also.

If you are interested in sharing a tech talk in the future, please reach out to: [masked]

name: Monthly Flutter Meetup

group.name: Google Developer Group of the Capital Region

description:
Details

Join the Flutter Special Interest Group (SIG) formed from within the Google Developer Group of the Capital Region. We'll take a close look at and get hands-on with Flutter https://flutter.io, Google’s new framework for building high-quality cross-platform mobile apps on Android and iOS in record time. It promises native apps with high performance and low development.

Advantages like really well-working hot-reload, complete code sharing for both platforms and a modern, reactive UI framework are just too good to be ignored. Some of the Flutter’s strengths are the easiness to build a fully customized animated graph and the visual highlight of beautiful apps. Flutter works with existing code, is used by developers and organizations around the world, and is free and open source.

Join us to see what it brings to the table for the mobile app developers and learn how to get started to design, develop and deploy Flutter apps.

Come to see how Flutter and the architecture patterns that can help give your apps a testable, reusable, and cohesive structure.

After the talk, you hopefully will have a better picture of what Flutter is capable of, its state of maturity and which use-cases it’s already great to be taken for.

Feel free to bring your own laptop to follow along with Flutter install.

You can use the following link to install it.

https://flutter.io/get-started/install

Follow along with a Codelab intro to Flutter

https://codelabs.developers.google.com/codelabs/flutter/#0

Agenda:

5:00 - 5:30 Food, Drinks, and Networking

5:30 - 5:45 Opening Remarks, Meetup announcements

5:45 - 6:30 Presentation: Introduction & Getting Started with Flutter

6:30 - 7:30 Codelab

7:30 – 8:00 - Meetup wrap-up, closing comments, and Networking

When:

Tuesday, February 12, 2019

5:00 PM to 8:00 PM

Where:

Jahnel Group

242 Union St Â· Schenectady, NY

==================

Environment setup

The event will be hands-on, so make sure to bring your laptop and setup your environment in advance and be ready to code.

For the Flutter Codelab, please do the following:

You need two pieces of software to complete this lab: the Flutter SDK, and an editor. This codelab assumes Android Studio/Visual Studio Code, but you can use your preferred editor.

You can run this Codelab using any of the following devices:

A physical device (Android or iOS) connected to your computer and set to developer mode.
The iOS simulator. (Requires installing XCode tools.)
The Android emulator. (Requires setup in Android Studio.)
For the App Engine Codelab, please sign up for a Google Cloud Platform account, and have a browser and editor ready to go.

For the Actions Codelab, please sign up for a Google Cloud Platform account, and have a browser ready to go.

See you all there!

What we are about:

Whether you are just starting a new Flutter project, or an experienced developer looking to discuss advanced topics, you are welcome to join our group and share your ideasÂ with us!

Details:
Join the Google Developer Group of the Capital Region -Â Flutter GroupÂ We will take a look at FlutterÂ  https://flutter.io/ Â to investigate what it brings to the table for mobile app developers. We will learn how to get started using Flutter to design, develop and deployÂ native apps with high performance and low development costs.Â Flutter works with existing code, is used by developers and organizations around the worldÂ and is free and open source.

We will work on a very simple Flutter app using a step-by-step Google tutorial. Together we will discover advantages like hot-reload, complete code sharing for both platforms and a modern, reactive UI framework. We will discussÂ which architecture patterns can help give your Flutter
apps a testable, reusable, and cohesive structure.

After the talk, you hopefully will have a better picture of what Flutter is capable of, its state of maturity and which use-cases for which it is already being used.
